headline.main: FULFILLING AMBITIONS IN THEIR AFTER HOURS

results.snippet: WHEN Helene Gurfein was growing up in Brooklyn, she dreamed about becoming a musical comedy star a la Jane Powell or Kathryn Grayson.  ''My main claim to fame,'' she said, ''was that when I was 7 or 8, I could hit the same high note that Kate Smith...

byline.original: By JUDY KLEMESRUD

results.lead_paragraph: WHEN Helene Gurfein was growing up in Brooklyn, she dreamed about becoming a musical comedy star a la Jane Powell or Kathryn Grayson. ''My main claim to fame,'' she said, ''was that when I was 7 or 8, I could hit the same high note that Kate Smith hit when she sang 'God Bless America.' '' Today Miss Gurfein is the manager of a Manhattan personnel agency, Broadmore Associates. But she hasn't completely abandoned her childhood dream. She is among the 200 members of the New York Choral Society, an amateur group that meets every Tuesday night and gives three concerts a year at Carnegie Hall. Miss Gurfein, who is in her 40's, is among the many adults who, when they were children, dreamed of growing up and having a glamorous career, such as singer, dancer, actor, fireman, astronaut, professional athlete, artist or brain surgeon.

headline.main: EX-ASTRONAUTS AS SALESMEN

results.snippet: The boyish grin of Charles Conrad Jr., the former astronaut, now adorns magazine advertisements for his company's jetliners. The intrepid gaze of Frank Borman, who circled the moon as commander of the Apollo 8 mission, looks out from television...

byline.original: By ERIC PACE

results.lead_paragraph: The boyish grin of Charles Conrad Jr., the former astronaut, now adorns magazine advertisements for his company's jetliners. The intrepid gaze of Frank Borman, who circled the moon as commander of the Apollo 8 mission, looks out from television commercials plugging the airline he runs. The confident charm of Eugene A. Cernan, the 11th man on the moon, is used on foreign oilmen on behalf of his Houston petroleum company. Former astronauts, who put in time as spokesmen, pitchmen and front men, are finding it far less lonely and much more profitable in the marketplace than in space and on the moon. All told, almost half of the 38 astronauts who have left the space program and the armed services - by resignation or retirement - have entered the world of business, doing work that includes advertising, sales, marketing and development.

headline.main: SPACE AND THE AMERICAN VISION

results.snippet: John Noble Wilford, science correspondent of The Times, has covered the space program since the early 1960's. By John Noble Wilford o much rides on the fires of Canaveral, the explosions of energy that overcome gravity and push tons of crafted...
results.lead_paragraph: John Noble Wilford, science correspondent of The Times, has covered the space program since the early 1960's. By John Noble Wilford o much rides on the fires of Canaveral, the explosions of energy that overcome gravity and push tons of crafted metal high into the sky and out of sight into that infinite frontier known as space. The fires are a testing. A people are testing themselves in relation to their heritage of steamboats, Conestoga wagons, railroads and airplanes, seeking reassurance that over the years the old vigor and resourcefulness have not left them. A people are testing their resolve to reach beyond the ordinary and thereby, if history repeats, magnify the human spirit.

headline.main: News Summary; MONDAY, APRIL 6, 1981

results.snippet: International Leonid I. Brezhnev flew to Prague to attend a meeting of the Czechoslovak Communist Party. Soon after his arrival the Soviet leader and Gustav Husak, the Czechoslovak party chief, met for talks. Mr. Brezhnev's trip comes amid...
results.lead_paragraph: International Leonid I. Brezhnev flew to Prague to attend a meeting of the Czechoslovak Communist Party. Soon after his arrival the Soviet leader and Gustav Husak, the Czechoslovak party chief, met for talks. Mr. Brezhnev's trip comes amid speculation in Moscow and Eastern Europe that a Soviet decision to move on Poland will be made in the next few days. Meanwhile, East Germany's official press agency reported that thousands of fresh troops had joined the extended Warsaw Pact maneuvers. (Page A1, Column 6.) President Reagan sent a message to Leonid I. Brezhnev, expressing extreme concern over the Soviet threat to Poland, according to an American official. The the President was said to have used ''strong language.'' (A10:1-2.)

headline.main: NEW GENERATION OF ASTRONAUTS POISED FOR SHUTTLE ERA

results.snippet: It is supposed to happen this way: Shortly before 1 P.M. next Sunday, 20 years to the day after Russia's Yuri Gagarin became the first human being to fly in space, the most technologically elegant spacecraft ever built will come hurtling down out...

byline.original: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: It is supposed to happen this way: Shortly before 1 P.M. next Sunday, 20 years to the day after Russia's Yuri Gagarin became the first human being to fly in space, the most technologically elegant spacecraft ever built will come hurtling down out of earth orbit. Flashing across the North Pacific, it will undergo a gradual metamorphosis. By the time it passes over Big Sur, it will have been transformed from a ballistic spacecraft into an aerodynamic glider. And when its commander, John W. Young, nurses the space shuttle Columbia to a dead-stick landing at Edwards Air Force Base in the Mojave Desert in southern California, the era of routine, workaday space travel will have dawned. Ready to greet that dawn is a whole new family of spacefaring Americans and Europeans consisting of about 80 young men and women. Two-thirds of them have been appointed astronauts or astronaut candidates only in the last three years.

headline.main: Special Shuttle Issue; NOTHING LIKE IT HAS EVER FLOWN BEFORE

results.snippet: THE space shuttle is unlike any other space vehicle ever constructed, the differences being chiefly rooted in its technical sophistication, the novelty of its many roles and its design for reuse on at least 100 missions.   The craft has been...

byline.original: By Walter Sullivan

results.lead_paragraph: THE space shuttle is unlike any other space vehicle ever constructed, the differences being chiefly rooted in its technical sophistication, the novelty of its many roles and its design for reuse on at least 100 missions. The craft has been designed not only to shuttle cargo back and forth between Earth orbit and the ground but also to conduct rescue missions, collect film and data from satellites, repair spacecraft, construct space facilities and inspect orbiting craft. In orbit, the shuttle consists of three sections. The forward one houses the flight crew and specialists in a casual, shirt-sleeve setting. The elongated central section, with four doors that open into space, carries the cargo.

headline.kicker: TV NETWORKS PLAN LIVE COVERAGE OF SPACE SHUTTLE CAPTION
headline.main: The New York Times/Keith Meyers Martin Bell of the British Broadcasting Corporation taping a report from Cape Canaveral, Fla.

results.snippet: All three major television networks and the Cable News Network have planned live coverage of the launching, re-entry and landing of the space shuttle.   At 11:30 o'clock tonight, both CBS News, with Dan Rather, and NBC News, with John Chancellor,...
results.lead_paragraph: All three major television networks and the Cable News Network have planned live coverage of the launching, re-entry and landing of the space shuttle. At 11:30 o'clock tonight, both CBS News, with Dan Rather, and NBC News, with John Chancellor, will offer special half-hour previews of the mission. The ABC News ''Nightline'' program will present a flight preview at the same time.

headline.main: LONG-RANGE POSTURE OF ADMINISTRATION ON SPACE PROGRAM REMAINS UNCERTAIN

results.snippet: If the skies over Florida are clear Friday, America's long-stalled manned space flight program will resume, but the space shuttle Columbia will be flying through clouds of political uncertainty.   The Reagan Administration, still without a science...

byline.original: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: If the skies over Florida are clear Friday, America's long-stalled manned space flight program will resume, but the space shuttle Columbia will be flying through clouds of political uncertainty. The Reagan Administration, still without a science adviser or a new head for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, has not articulated a long-range or detailed philosophy on the value of continued space endeavors. Thus far, President Reagan has had little to say publicly about the shuttle, and efforts today to find a spokesman at the White House to express Mr. Reagan's views for the record were unavailing. This leaves Mr. Reagan in the political position of being able to embrace the program as his own if Friday's shot succeeds or to remain aloof if it fails.

headline.main: Is the Shuttle Worth Rooting For?

results.snippet: At dawn tomorrow the space shuttle Columbia, three years behind schedule and way over budget, is due to blast off on the riskiest, most technologically challenging space mission yet. Though this radically new venture is even more demanding than the...
results.lead_paragraph: At dawn tomorrow the space shuttle Columbia, three years behind schedule and way over budget, is due to blast off on the riskiest, most technologically challenging space mission yet. Though this radically new venture is even more demanding than the landing on the moon, the mood of the public is subdued, and many Americans are mystified. Will a successful flight mark a milestone in man's conquest of space - or the evolution of a technological white elephant? If all goes well, the flight of the shuttle will be an unquestionable technological achievement. It is the first reusable space vehicle, designed to make a hundred trips aloft. It has had to meet far higher engineering standards than conventional space vehicles, which can be battered and scorched during the single mission for which they are built, then discarded.

headline.main: COMPUTER PROBLEM WILL DELAY SHUTTLE AT LEAST TWO DAYS

results.snippet: A mysterious computer breakdown caused postponement of the launching of the space shuttle Columbia today, and space agency officials pressed to reschedule it for Sunday morning.   The earliest the orbital test mission could get under way is 6:50...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: A mysterious computer breakdown caused postponement of the launching of the space shuttle Columbia today, and space agency officials pressed to reschedule it for Sunday morning. The earliest the orbital test mission could get under way is 6:50 A.M. Sunday. But until the computer problem in the spaceship could be corrected the officials were unable to say when the re-usable winged Columbia would be cleared for another launching attempt. Tonight engineers at the Johnson Space Center in Houston identified the source of the malfunction as a timing fault in one set of spaceship computers that disrupted communications with the backup computer.

headline.main: AGE OF SPACE TRAVEL OPENED 20 YEARS AGO TODAY

results.snippet: It was 20 years ago today that a man was hurled for the first time into space, propelling mankind into the age of space travel.  The man was a Russian, Maj. Yuri A. Gagarin, who on April 12, 1961 took a 108-minute spin around the earth at a speed...

byline.original: BY DENA KLEIMAN

results.lead_paragraph: It was 20 years ago today that a man was hurled for the first time into space, propelling mankind into the age of space travel. The man was a Russian, Maj. Yuri A. Gagarin, who on April 12, 1961 took a 108-minute spin around the earth at a speed of more than 17,000 miles an hour, six times faster than man had ever traveled before, and at a height of 187 miles. He returned to earth safe and an international hero. Some called him ''the Columbus of the Interplanetary Age.'' ''Let the capitalist countries try to catch up,'' said Nikita S. Khrushchev, the Soviet leader, in declaring a victory over the United States and its space efforts. Three weeks later, on May 5, the United States sent up Comdr. Alan B. Shepard Jr. on a suborbital flight.

headline.kicker: PROBLEM IN SHUTTLE IS REPORTED SOLVED
headline.main: WAY CLEAR FOR TEST

results.snippet: Space agency officials announced today that they had resolved a computer problem on the space shuttle Columbia, clearing the way for another launching attempt tomorrow morning.   Launching crews at the Kennedy Space Center resumed the countdown at...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Space agency officials announced today that they had resolved a computer problem on the space shuttle Columbia, clearing the way for another launching attempt tomorrow morning. Launching crews at the Kennedy Space Center resumed the countdown at 6 P.M. today, aiming toward a liftoff at 7 A.M. for the shuttle's first orbital flight. Predictions of cloudy weather, however, added some uncertainty to the launching prospects. Astronauts Briefed on Problem If the Columbia does make its debut as now planned, the mission would occur on the 20th anniversary of the first flight of a human in space. Yuri A. Gagarin, the Soviet astronaut, made his one-orbit flight April 12, 1961.

headline.main: STRIP USED FOR TRAINING ASTRONAUTS IS PREPARED FOR EMERGENCY LANDING

results.snippet: If the astronauts flying the Columbia were forced to land at the Northrup Strip here after one orbit around the earth, they would aim for a huge white target visible from far out in space.   The 224-square-mile region, resembling a mountain-ringed...

byline.original: By WALTER SULLIVAN, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: If the astronauts flying the Columbia were forced to land at the Northrup Strip here after one orbit around the earth, they would aim for a huge white target visible from far out in space. The 224-square-mile region, resembling a mountain-ringed patch of Antarctica transported to New Mexico, would be familiar terrain, for it was here that the astronauts trained in a Grumman Gulfstream executive-type jet that was radically modified to fly like the shuttle. However, the seven-mile unpaved landing strip of hard-packed gypsum would look very different from the way they remembered it in their training. Poised alongside it would be a convoy of fire trucks, crash wagons with people in escape suits, specialists with sensors to detect explosion hazards, three crash rescue helicopters, vans with television crews on the roofs and six buses aimed away from the strip for a quick getaway.

headline.main: WINGING IT TO WASHINGTON

results.snippet: Francis X. Clines is a reporter for The Times's Washington bureau. By Francis X. Clines uring an awful day of delays at New York City's La Guardia Airport, a planeload of Eastern Air Lines shuttle passengers were kept strapped and wondering in...
results.lead_paragraph: Francis X. Clines is a reporter for The Times's Washington bureau. By Francis X. Clines uring an awful day of delays at New York City's La Guardia Airport, a planeload of Eastern Air Lines shuttle passengers were kept strapped and wondering in their narrowly packed seats and, as precious business time slipped by, some of them tried to rebel creatively. At the instigation of Carl Bernstein, Washington bureau chief of ABC News, they composed a group letter of complaint to Frank Borman, Eastern's chief executive. ''Dear Captain Astronaut,'' the desperately merry band began, ''we are being held captive on your airplane. ...'' Eventually they were set free and the letter was mailed, but their originality went unrequited. ''We got back a form letter,'' recalls Mr. Bernstein, who found this impersonal touch amusingly typical of the shuttle he has come to know, to rely on and, he adds, to resent after more than a decade's regular patronage.

headline.main: SKY IS THE LIMIT FOR CITIZEN'S BACKYARD ROCKET SHIP

results.snippet: Bob's Space Program lags behind that of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. As NASA's Columbia waits to streak into orbit 173 miles above earth, Bob's ''space shuttle'' is still unfinished, sitting in his driveway next to a can of...

byline.original: By WILLIAM E. GEIST

results.lead_paragraph: Bob's Space Program lags behind that of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. As NASA's Columbia waits to streak into orbit 173 miles above earth, Bob's ''space shuttle'' is still unfinished, sitting in his driveway next to a can of grass clippings in Saratoga, Calif. There have been delays. Bob, who is Robert C. Truax, says he has to stop from time to time to hunt for the pliers or to go to the hardware store for screws or to let the dogs out. Still, Mr. Truax believes that the craft he is building in and around his garage will be ready for its first manned suborbital flight next year.

headline.main: BIGGER SPACE STATIONS ARE SOVIET GOAL

results.snippet: As the American space shuttle Columbia stands on its Cape Canaveral launch pad, the shadows of events 20 years past hover about its 184-foot-tall metal structure. It was at Cape Canaveral on April 12, 1961, that a Redstone rocket waited to lift...

byline.original: By THEODORE SHABAD

results.lead_paragraph: As the American space shuttle Columbia stands on its Cape Canaveral launch pad, the shadows of events 20 years past hover about its 184-foot-tall metal structure. It was at Cape Canaveral on April 12, 1961, that a Redstone rocket waited to lift what the United States hoped would be the first man in space. That day, the Soviet Union boosted Major Yuri A. Gagarin into a 108-minute single orbit of Earth. The Soviet Union's historic achievement culminated more than three years of scientific and technological effort that had begun with the first Sputnik satellite launch in October 1957 and would end 11 years later with the United States landing the first men on the moon. Now the space shuttle has become the centerpiece of America's space program. The Soviet Union has taken a different path in space exploration, leading to manned orbiting space stations.

headline.main: Index; Voyage of Columbia
'YEEEOW!' AND DOGGONE!' ARE SHOUTED ON BEACHES AS CROWDS WATCH LIFTOFF

results.snippet: They came from every corner of the country and spread out by the thousands on beaches across the Indian River from the Kennedy Space Center. The sun had just risen over the Atlantic behind them and their eyes were riveted on the space shuttle...
results.lead_paragraph: They came from every corner of the country and spread out by the thousands on beaches across the Indian River from the Kennedy Space Center. The sun had just risen over the Atlantic behind them and their eyes were riveted on the space shuttle Columbia, pointing straight up on its launching pad and only a moment away from a thunderous liftoff. Four thousand others with more impressive credentials crowded onto makeshift viewing stands along Mosquito Lagoon three and a half miles from the launch site. With two minutes to go, Neil Armstrong, the first man to walk on the moon, scrambled to the top of the stands to get a better view and Gov. Edmund G. Brown of California made a final adjustment to his field glasses.

headline.main: A CURIOUS CONVOY IS SET TO GREET SHUTTLE IN CALIFORNIA

results.snippet: Four men and one woman, wearing astronaut-style spacesuits and carrying instruments to sniff the air for toxic and explosive vapors, will be the first persons to greet the astronauts John W. Young and Robert L. Crippen when they return to earth.  ...

byline.original: By ROBERT LINDSEY, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Four men and one woman, wearing astronaut-style spacesuits and carrying instruments to sniff the air for toxic and explosive vapors, will be the first persons to greet the astronauts John W. Young and Robert L. Crippen when they return to earth. After its 54 1/2-hour maiden flight, the space shuttle Columbia is scheduled to touch down on a vast, sun-caked dry lake here. Minutes later, 21 vehicles, a motorized convoy unlike any ever assembled before, will begin racing across the lake bed toward the ship. Led by a motor home outwardly similar to those used by thousands of Americans for recreational trips, the convoy will contain safety inspectors in space suits, a wind machine like those Hollywood directors use to simulate storms, crash trucks and a curious array of other vehicles designed to insure the safety of the astronauts and their spaceship once they have landed. A fleet of rescue helicopters will be standing by to act in case the ship crashes in the nearby hills or to serve as airborne ambulances if it becomes necessary to move the astronauts to a specially alerted hospital trauma team more than 60 miles away.

headline.main: ROBERT L. CRIPPEN

results.snippet: While John Young was establishing himself in the last two decades as one of the premier astronauts of the early space age, Bob Crippen was waiting. For 15 years he waited. That is how long he was an astronaut before he made his first trip into...

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: While John Young was establishing himself in the last two decades as one of the premier astronauts of the early space age, Bob Crippen was waiting. For 15 years he waited. That is how long he was an astronaut before he made his first trip into space. But if he felt any acute frustration during the long, dry years that led to today's launching of the space shuttle Columbia, it is belied by his bright disposition, his affability, his aura of casual confidence. His flashing teeth and slightly aging good looks evoke similar reactions from many who meet him: If Hollywood was casting the Columbia crew, it would surely pick Capt. Robert Laurel Crippen of the Navy.

headline.main: SOME WEPT, SOME SLEPT AND SOME SAW LIFTOFF AS A BIG WASTE OF MONEY

results.snippet: Much of the world joined Americans early yesterday morning in watching the space shuttle Columbia thunder away from its launching site on Cape Canaveral, Fla., and streak into the earth's orbit.   The liftoff, transmitted by satellite to millions...

byline.original: By RONALD SULLIVAN

results.lead_paragraph: Much of the world joined Americans early yesterday morning in watching the space shuttle Columbia thunder away from its launching site on Cape Canaveral, Fla., and streak into the earth's orbit. The liftoff, transmitted by satellite to millions of television viewers, was widely interpreted as a successful American resurgence in space flight on the 20th anniversary of the first manned flight into space by Yuri A. Gagarin, the Soviet astronaut. Unlike the earlier Mercury and Apollo space launchings, which generated so much initial excitement and a clear sense of American technological achievement, yesterday's takeoff was viewed by many Americans with far more confidence that it would succeed and with a quieter sense of pride and accomplishment when it did. Marty McCarthy, an electronics technician in Chicago, and his wife, Joyce, represented a range of reaction in this country. Mr. McCarthy said he was so excited that tears came to his eyes as he watched television in his bedroom and saw the Columbia roar off its pad and soar into space.

headline.main: JOHN W. YOUNG

results.snippet: With his unlined face, his mere hint of gray hair and his sometimes wryly self-effacing manner, John W. Young doesn't exactly look or act the part. But at the age of 50 he is the chief, the astronaut's astronaut, the dean of the corps, the wise old...

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: With his unlined face, his mere hint of gray hair and his sometimes wryly self-effacing manner, John W. Young doesn't exactly look or act the part. But at the age of 50 he is the chief, the astronaut's astronaut, the dean of the corps, the wise old man among spacefarers. With today's successful launching of the space shuttle Columbia, Mr. Young became the first astronaut to fly in space five times. No human being, American or Russian, has been into space as many times, on as many different kinds of missions, as he.

headline.main: EXPLORERS TO ADMIT WOMEN

results.snippet: After 75 years of voyages that rocketed to the moon and plumbed the depths of the oceans, the men of the Explorers Club crossed a new frontier yesterday and agreed to admit women into their ranks.   ''Tradition and exploration are antithetical,''...

byline.original: By JOSH BARBANEL

results.lead_paragraph: After 75 years of voyages that rocketed to the moon and plumbed the depths of the oceans, the men of the Explorers Club crossed a new frontier yesterday and agreed to admit women into their ranks. ''Tradition and exploration are antithetical,'' said Dr. Charles F. Brush, an archeologist who stepped down yesterday as club president, after the results of a secret membership vote were announced.

headline.main: Quotations of the Day

results.snippet: ''That was one fantastic ride. I highly recommend it.'' - Capt.  Robert L. Crippen, on his first space mission.
results.lead_paragraph: ''That was one fantastic ride. I highly recommend it.'' - Capt. Robert L. Crippen, on his first space mission.

headline.kicker: SHUTTLE ROCKETS INTO ORBIT ON FIRST FLIGHT
headline.main: SOME TILES FALL OFF, BUT NASA SEES NO DANGER

results.snippet: The space shuttle Columbia, its rockets spewing orange fire and a long trail of white vapor, blasted its way into earth orbit today, carrying two American astronauts on a daring journey to test the world's first re-usable spaceship.   Soon after...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Columbia, its rockets spewing orange fire and a long trail of white vapor, blasted its way into earth orbit today, carrying two American astronauts on a daring journey to test the world's first re-usable spaceship. Soon after they settled into orbit, John W. Young, a civilian, and Capt. Robert L. Crippen of the Navy focused a television camera on the Columbia's tail section and discovered that more than a dozen heat-shielding tiles had ripped off, possibly because of the stresses of launching. Project officials said that the tile loss should not shorten the flight or endanger the lives of the astronauts when the Columbia plunges back into the atmosphere, glowing red-hot from frictional heat, to attempt a runway landing Tuesday. The projected 36-orbit, 54 1/2-hour flight is scheduled to end at Edwards Air Force Base in California. 'We've Got a Super Vehicle' ''I'm just not concerned about it,'' Neil B. Hutchinson, a flight director at Mission Control in Houston, said in discussing the tile problem at a news conference this afternoon. ''We've got a super vehicle up there.''

headline.main: NATION'S HOPES CARRIED ALOFT BY SHUTTLE

results.snippet: For two thunderous minutes this morning, a plume of white fire ascended into the Florida sky before disappearing, and a mighty cheer arose from the crowd below.   ''Goodbye, you beautiful Columbia,'' a woman yelled. In common with approximately one...

byline.original: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

results.lead_paragraph: For two thunderous minutes this morning, a plume of white fire ascended into the Florida sky before disappearing, and a mighty cheer arose from the crowd below. ''Goodbye, you beautiful Columbia,'' a woman yelled. In common with approximately one million other spectators, she had spent a mostly sleepless night swatting mosquitoes and listening to announcements. Tears streaming from her eyes, she added, ''Come home to us safely!'' For everyone, the launching of the space shuttle had been a great show, as beautiful as a Fourth of July fireworks display. Those who had come just for the show went away satisfied.

headline.main: IN ORBIT: 'THE SPACESHIP IS PERFORMING BEAUTIFUL'

results.snippet: Following are excerpts from conversations the astronauts had with Mission Control in Houston and with Vice President George Bush, as recorded by The New York Times:   HOUSTON: Hello, Columbia, this if Houston back with you through Tula.  We'll be...
results.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from conversations the astronauts had with Mission Control in Houston and with Vice President George Bush, as recorded by The New York Times: HOUSTON: Hello, Columbia, this if Houston back with you through Tula. We'll be with you for 14 minutes, over. CAPT. ROBERT L. CRIPPEN: Also got TV set up for... HOUSTON: Okay Cripp. We thank you very much as we're starting on those I've got a message to read up to the two of you. Orroral passes thanks to you for the hometown music.

headline.main: DRAMA IN 'STENGELESE: YOU CAN LOOK IT UP

results.snippet: The conversation turned to languages, and the creator, expert and sole practitioner of the inimitable, sometimes inscrutable, prolix and amazin' language, Stengelese, addressed himself to it.   Casey Stengel said: ''I started out to be a dentist....

byline.original: By IRA BERKOW

results.lead_paragraph: The conversation turned to languages, and the creator, expert and sole practitioner of the inimitable, sometimes inscrutable, prolix and amazin' language, Stengelese, addressed himself to it. Casey Stengel said: ''I started out to be a dentist. The dean of my school said, 'Why don't you be an orthodontist?' That way I could have got a lot of rich kids and put a black filling in their mouth. The dean said, 'Always try to be a little different.' And today I make speeches all over. People ask me, 'Casey, how can you speak so much when you don't talk English too good?' Well, I've been invited to Europe, and I say, 'They don't speak English over there too good, either.' '' The discourse took place in the Met dugout on a summer day about a decade after Stengel's retirement as manager and a year before he died, at age 85, in 1975. A shock of white hair fell boyishly across the side of his face, a face as wrinkled as an elephant hide. His blue eyes were rheumy, and he wiped them with a large handkerchief. He wore a natty dark suit and was shod in black slippers because his feet hurt, but he'd jump up on bandy legs to make a point, gesturing and declaiming in his froggy voice.

headline.main: COLUMBIA RETURNS: SHUTTLE ERA OPENS

results.snippet: The space shuttle Columbia rocketed out of orbit and glided to a safe landing on the desert here today to conclude the successful first demonstration of a bold new approach to extraterrestrial travel, the re-usable winged spaceship.   Heralding its...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Columbia rocketed out of orbit and glided to a safe landing on the desert here today to conclude the successful first demonstration of a bold new approach to extraterrestrial travel, the re-usable winged spaceship. Heralding its triumphant return with a sharp double sonic boom, one of technology's fanfares, the 122-foot-long Columbia appeared in the clear blue sky, soared over the base, looped back and touched its wheels down in the wash of a mirage on the hard-packed clay of a dry lake bed. Touchdown came at 1:21 P.M., Eastern standard time. ''Welcome home, Columbia!'' was the simple message from Joseph Allen in Mission Control. 215 Miles an Hour Capt. Robert L. Crippen of the Navy and John W. Young brought the 80-ton gliding vehicle with its stubby delta wings to a smooth landing at a speed of 215 miles an hour, about twice the velocity of a jetliner landing.

headline.main: OLD MAN OF THE MISSION EXCEEDS HIS JUNIOR IN JOY

results.snippet: Having made history, the dean of the spacefarers and his rookie companion stepped onto the dust of the Mojave Desert with bounce in their steps, but it was the normally unflappable veteran of five space flights and a walk on the moon who showed the...

byline.original: By WOLFGANG SAXON

results.lead_paragraph: Having made history, the dean of the spacefarers and his rookie companion stepped onto the dust of the Mojave Desert with bounce in their steps, but it was the normally unflappable veteran of five space flights and a walk on the moon who showed the jubilation of the event as he strode about, flapping his arms, to inspect the Columbia. John W. Young, commander of the mission, gave a thumbs-up signal to the ground crews and punched the air after leaving the craft's cockpit where he and his junior pilot, Capt. Robert L. Crippen of the Navy, had bided their time - Mr. Young with obvious impatience - for an hour after the 1:21 P.M. landing. Mr. Young, who is 50 years old and has ridden more space missions of greater variety than any other human being, exultantly examined the life-saving thermal tiles on the Columbia's underbelly. ''You can't believe what a flying machine this is!'' he said. ''It's really something special.''

headline.main: Soviet Astronaut Shows Concern About Military Role of Spaceship

results.snippet: Maj. Gen. Aleksei A. Leonov of the Soviet Air Force, the first astronaut to ''walk'' in space, today said that this week's mission of the space shuttle Columbia was a major technical success but was financially wasteful and dangerous.  He also said...

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Maj. Gen. Aleksei A. Leonov of the Soviet Air Force, the first astronaut to ''walk'' in space, today said that this week's mission of the space shuttle Columbia was a major technical success but was financially wasteful and dangerous. He also said he was alarmed by official American statements that the mission was intended for military as well as civilian purposes. Speaking at a news conference on a visit here to mark the 20th anniversary of man's first flight in space, he said, ''I was overcome by numbness when I heard the American announcement that the Columbia's research mission was not only scientific, but also military.''

headline.main: BREZHNEV HINTS HE WANTS TALKS ON SPACE ARMS CURBS

results.snippet: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, implied today that the Soviet Union was ready to resume negotiations with the United States on banning military activity in outer space.   Though he did not refer to the successful flight of the American space...

byline.original: By ANTHONY AUSTIN, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, implied today that the Soviet Union was ready to resume negotiations with the United States on banning military activity in outer space. Though he did not refer to the successful flight of the American space shuttle Columbia, his remarks, made at a Soviet space ceremony, appeared to reflect Moscow's stated concern over the military potential of the shuttle program. In the minimal coverage they gave to Columbia's liftoff and its return to earth, Soviet television and Tass, the official press agency, portrayed the new spaceship as primarily an instrument for testing laser weapons and ''killer satellites'' in space. In advance of the test flight, the Soviet press accused the Pentagon of seeking to turn space into a battle arena.

headline.main: YONDER AND BACK

results.snippet: LATE off the drawing boards, tardy in development, delayed off the launching pad, the space shuttle Columbia was running some 24 hours behind schedule this weekend as engineers at Edwards Air Force Base in California continued their elaborate...
results.lead_paragraph: LATE off the drawing boards, tardy in development, delayed off the launching pad, the space shuttle Columbia was running some 24 hours behind schedule this weekend as engineers at Edwards Air Force Base in California continued their elaborate post-flight inspections. But so what? After the almost faultless flight and spectacular, ontime landing last week, no one was complaining. This ''brave adventure,'' said President Reagan, has ''put new worlds within closer reach and more knowledge within our grasp.'' ''We're really not too far, the human race isn't, from going to the stars,'' observed astronaut John W. Young. And in a wry reference to the history of engineering mishaps and doubts over the shuttle's workability, the director of the Johnson Space Center in Houston, Christopher C. Kraft Jr., noted, ''We just became infinitely smarter.''

headline.main: THIRTEEN RUNAWAY SLAVES AND DAVID BRADLEY

results.snippet: IN his first novel, ''South Street,'' David Bradley cast an incisive eye on the inhabitants of one of Philadelphia's more colorful inner-city thoroughfares and displayed a distinct flare for Richard Pryor's wry kind of humor. Although Mr. Bradley's...

byline.original: By MEL WATKINS; Mel Watkins is an editor of The New York Times Book Review

results.lead_paragraph: IN his first novel, ''South Street,'' David Bradley cast an incisive eye on the inhabitants of one of Philadelphia's more colorful inner-city thoroughfares and displayed a distinct flare for Richard Pryor's wry kind of humor. Although Mr. Bradley's second novel, ''The Chaneysville Incident,'' is by no stretch of the imagination humorous, its author, in person, exhibits the same sidelong view of life that en-livened the narrative voice of his first book. Mr. Bradley, whose father was a minister and historian, was born in Bedford, Pa. in 1950 and grew up in a rural area where he estimates there were about 100 blacks in a county with a population of 30,000. ''The southern part of Bedford County was originally a part of Maryland,'' he says. ''And the town of Bedford is perilously close to the Mason-Dixon line. This is one of those places where the stories about one brother fighting for the Union Army and another for the Confederacy originated. It was not that hospitable for blacks - or that comfortable. ''It's a farm country, and I grew up feeding chickens,'' he says, ''but there were always books around our house. My father attended the University of Pittsburgh and began his doctoral work at New York University before settling in Bedford. He wrote several books on the history of the Methodist Church and published them privately.

headline.main: Explorers Club Discovers Women

results.snippet: For the New York-based Explorers Club, receiving women into the ranks of the brave and daring has loomed as a last frontier. Last week, it was conquered.

byline.original: By Eva Hoffman and Margot Slade

results.lead_paragraph: For the New York-based Explorers Club, receiving women into the ranks of the brave and daring has loomed as a last frontier. Last week, it was conquered.

headline.main: SENATE BEGINS HEARINGS ON BILL TO OUTLAW ABORTIONS

results.snippet: Senate conservatives opened their drive to outlaw abortions today as five doctors appeared on Capitol Hill and testified that human life begins at conception.   The hearings, convened by Senator John P. East, Republican of North Carolina, were...

byline.original: By BERNARD WEINRAUB, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Senate conservatives opened their drive to outlaw abortions today as five doctors appeared on Capitol Hill and testified that human life begins at conception. The hearings, convened by Senator John P. East, Republican of North Carolina, were interrupted by two brief demonstrations by supporters of the right to abortion and statements of protest were distributed by such groups as the American College of Obstetrics and Gynecology, the American Civil Liberties Union and the Planned Parenthood Federation of America. Senator East, a conservative who is a strong foe of abortion, said at the opening of the hearing that the statute under consideration was designed to ''vitiate, negate'' a 1973 Supreme Court ruling that gave women a constitutional right to an abortion. The statute is sponsored by Representative Henry J. Hyde, Republican of Illinois, and Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina.

headline.main: ABORTION LESSON: ZYGOTES, GAMETES AND WOMAN

results.snippet: The Senator was informed that he began life as a zygote.''Each of us started life as a zygote,'' the scientist testified, speaking of the simple-cell state of conception and not bothering to add what was abundantly evident in the crowded,...

byline.original: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The Senator was informed that he began life as a zygote.''Each of us started life as a zygote,'' the scientist testified, speaking of the simple-cell state of conception and not bothering to add what was abundantly evident in the crowded, contentious hearing room: that life's divisions and complexities can grow greatly beyond the zygote stage. Senator John P. East, a Republican from North Carolina who opposes abortion, was running the hearing, surveying a packed room heatedly divided in two by the issue. He listened to all five scientists who were opening witnesses agree on when life begins.

headline.main: Experts Clash at Abortion Hearings

results.snippet: The measure under consideration was a bill declaring that human life begins at conception, thus making abortion equivalent to murder and criminally punishable. The sessions, held in a packed Senate hearing room over two days last week, were as...
results.lead_paragraph: The measure under consideration was a bill declaring that human life begins at conception, thus making abortion equivalent to murder and criminally punishable. The sessions, held in a packed Senate hearing room over two days last week, were as highly charged as the issue itself. All five witnesses called by a Senate Judiciary subcommittee on the first day testified that life begins at conception. Prof. Hymie Gordon, chairman of the Department of Medical Genetics at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., said this was ''an established fact.'' Dr. Jerome Lejeune, professor of fundamental genetics at the University of Rene Descartes in Paris, compared the fertilized egg to Tom Thumb or an astronaut. Dr. Micheline Matthews-Roth said ''It is scientifically correct to say that an individual human life begins at conception, when egg and sperm join to form the zygote, and that this developing human always is a member of our species in all stages of life.''

headline.main: Notes On People; 2 Astronauts Plan Terrestrial Wedding, in Hawaii

results.snippet: Although they could very well be the first husband and wife in outer space, Dr. Margaret Rhea Seddon and Lieut. Cmdr. Robert Lee Gibson, both astronauts, will settle for a trip to Hawaii by conventional jet following their marriage May 30 in her...

byline.original: By Laurie Johnston and Robert McG. Thomas

results.lead_paragraph: Although they could very well be the first husband and wife in outer space, Dr. Margaret Rhea Seddon and Lieut. Cmdr. Robert Lee Gibson, both astronauts, will settle for a trip to Hawaii by conventional jet following their marriage May 30 in her home town of Murfreesboro, Tenn.
